titleStmt.title: RNA-seq dependent transcriptional analysis unveils gene expression profile in the intestine of sea cucumber Apostichopus japonicus during aestivation

affiliation.orgName: University of Chinese Academy of Sciences

analytic.title: RNA-seq dependent transcriptional analysis unveils gene expression profile in the intestine of sea cucumber Apostichopus japonicus during aestivation

biblStruct.note: Received 23 January 2014 Received in revised form 25 February 2014 Accepted 28 February 2014

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: Hypometabolism Differential gene expression Aestivation-arousal cycles Echinoderm Environmental stress NA, non-aestivation
RPKM, reads per kb million reads

abstract.p: The seasonal marine, the sea cucumber Apostichopus japonicus (Selenka, 1867), cycles annually between periods of torpor when water temperature is above about 25°C in summer and active life when temperature is below about 18°C. This species is a good candidate model organism for studies of environmentally-induced aestivation in marine invertebrates. Previous studies have examined various aspects of aestivation of A. japonicus, however, knowledge of the molecular regulation underpinning these events is still fragmentary. In the present study, we constructed a global gene expression profile of the intestine tissue of A. japonicus using RNA-seq to identify transcriptional responses associated with transitions between different states: non-aestivation (NA), deepaestivation (DA), and arousal from aestivation (AA). The analysis identified 1245 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) between DA vs. NA states, 1338 DEGs between AA vs. DA, and 1321 DEGs between AA vs. NA using the criteria |Log 2 Ratio| ≥ 1 and FDR ≤ 0.001. Of these, 25 of the most significant DEGs were verified by real-time PCR, showing trends in expression patterns that were almost in full concordance between the two techniques. GO analysis revealed that for DA vs. NA, 24 metabolic associated processes were highly enriched (corrected p value b 0.05) whereas for AA vs. NA, 12 transport and metabolism associated processes were significantly enriched (corrected p value b 0.05). Pathways associated with aestivation were also mined, and indicated that most DEGs were enriched in metabolic and signal transduction pathways in the deep aestivation stage. Two up pathways were significantly enriched at the arousal stage (ribosome and metabolism of xenobiotics by cytochrome P450 pathway). A set of key DEGs was identified that may play vital roles in aestivation; these involved metabolism, detoxification and tissue protection, and energy-expensive processes. Our work presents an overview of dynamic gene expression in torpor-arousal cycles during aestivation of A. japonicus and identifies a series of candidate genes and pathways for further research on the molecular mechanisms of aestivation.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Aestivation is a state of dormancy that is well known to be used by terrestrial animals for surviving environmental conditions of high temperature or aridity (Storey and Storey, 2012). However, aestivation can also occur among marine invertebrate animals although the phenomenon has received little attention to date. The sea cucumber Apostichopus japonicus (Selenka, 1867), a seasonal marine aestivator, cycles annually between periods of torpor when water temperature is above about 25°C in summer and active life when temperature is below about 18°C. This species has proved to be a good candidate model organism for studies of environmentally-induced aestivation in marine invertebrates. This species has attracted more and more scientific attention, due to its phylogenetic position (an invertebrate deuterostome) and its special physiological characters (Ji et al., 2008;Ortiz-Pineda et al., 2009;García-Arrarás and Dolmatov, 2010;Sun et al., 2013;Chen et al., 2013). A. japonicus is also an important aquatic species with high commercial and medicinal values in Japan, Korea and north of China (Liao, 1997). The annual period of aestivation usually lasts more than 4 months with a complete cessation of feeding and locomotion (Li et al., 1996). During this period the intestine degenerates into a very tiny filament associated with obvious hypometabolism of the whole animal (Li et al., 1996;Yang et al., 2005;Yang et al., 2006). This undoubtedly shortens the growing cycle of A. japonicus and brings economic losses.

The control of gene expression is crucial for any living organism and identification of the underlying mechanisms that allow organisms to switch between torpor and arousal are common central questions in the study of torpor among different organisms (Morin and Storey, 2009). Similar to the situation for mammalian hibernation, the transitions from an active non-aestivating state into deep aestivation and then arousal from prolonged aestivation include complex physiological and biochemical reorganization. Studies of gene expression profiles in response to circannual cycles offer an opportunity to understand the basic parts of this reorganization. Although physiological adaptations supporting sea cucumber aestivation have been well-researched (Yang et al., 2005;Yang et al., 2006;Gao et al., 2009), few attempts have been made to evaluate changes in gene transcript levels, and research on the underlying molecular mechanisms of sea cucumber aestivation is only the beginning. For example, Ji et al. (2008) reported that heat shock protein 70 (Hsp 70) levels decreased during aestivation. Recently, Du et al. (2012) constructed a profile of the differentially expressed genes (DEGs) between the active and aestivating states in sea cucumbers by combining the intestine, respiratory tree and coelomic fluid tissues and applying 454 life sequencing. We sequenced gene expression profile of the intestine from sea cucumbers under different aestivation stage (NA, DA and AA) using Illumina HiSeq™ 2000 (BGI, Shenzhen), which provides a better depth of sequencing compared to 454.

The present study undertakes an in-depth analysis of the transcriptome responses to aestivation by a single specific tissue (intestine) of the sea cucumber. Comparisons are made of three crucial life stages:(1) non-aestivation (NA) animals that have gone through the aestivation period, regenerated their intestinal tissue and returned to active status; (2) deep-aestivation (DA) animals that have stopped feeding and locomotion and the intestine had degenerated into a very tiny string (about 2-3 mm), usually after 15 days of continuous torpor; and (3) arousal from aestivation (AA) after the water temperature was reduced to 18°C for 2 days and animals showed renewed movement and feeding (feces in the intestine). The Illumina technology used here generated significantly more reads than the previous 454 life sequencing, providing us with much more information; e.g. 1245 DEGs (DA vs. NA), 1338 DEGs (AA vs. DA) and 1321 DEGs (AA vs. NA) were identified as compared with only 446 DEGs identified by Du et al.(2012). Furthermore, we were able to use the most complete reference library of A. japonicus to date to help annotate our results; this integrated the transcriptome of the regenerative body wall and the intestine constructed by our team (Sun et al., 2011) and another nine transcriptomes including all the tissues of sea cucumbers at different developmental stages (embryo, larva, white juvenile and black juvenile) and under different physiological conditions (Du et al., 2012). GO and pathway enrichment analysis were also applied to provide an overview of the main functions of the DEGs identified during aestivation. Our results identify the key candidate genes and indicate the potentially significant role of transcriptional regulation in torpor-arousal cycles during aestivation.

div.head: Animals
div.p: Adult individuals of the sea cucumber A. japonicus (80-120 g body mass) were collected from the coast of Qingdao (Shandong, China) in early March, and acclimated in seawater aquaria at 15°C for one week before use; sea cucumbers were fed once a day. All sea cucumbers were then divided randomly into either control or experimental groups. Sea cucumbers in the control non-aestivation (NA) group were kept at a constant temperature (about 15°C) throughout the experiment and individuals were sampled at the same times as their corresponding DA or AA group. Animals in the experimental group were slowly induced to aestivation by increasing the water temperature from 15°C to 25°C at a rate of 0.5°C per day. A temperature of 25°C was determined to be the threshold for entering aestivation in our previous study (Yang et al., 2006). Animals in deep aestivation (DA) were collected after 15 days at 25°C. Sea cucumbers had stopped feeding, and their movements, if any, were very limited. Other animals were sampled soon after arousing from torpor, after the water temperature was reduced to 18°C (at a rate of 0.5°C per day) and moving and feeding were observed in the experimental animals. In the present study, the AA animals were sampled after 2 days back at 18°C. The whole sampling process has been described in our previous study (Zhao et al., 2013). At each stage, 15 individuals were sacrificed (NA, DA and AA) and the intestine tissue was rapidly dissected out and frozen in liquid nitrogen for later analysis.

div.head: Preparation of cDNA library for sequencing
div.p: Total RNA was isolated from the intestine tissues at the above three stages of the circannual cycle of A. japonicus using an RNeasy mini kit including DNase-treatment with an RNase-free DNase (Qiagen Inc., Germany), following the manufacturer's instructions. RNA concentration and quality were determined using an Agilent 2100 bioanalyzer. Total RNA from 6 individuals per stage was pooled. The starting amount of RNA was 1 μg per pool (6 individuals). The following steps were performed at BGI-Shenzhen including mRNA enrichment, fragment interruption, addition of adapters, size selection, PCR amplification, and RNA-Seq. Briefly, mRNA was separated from the total RNA using oligo(dT) magnetic beads and broken into short fragments (approximately 200 bp) as templates for first strand cDNA and second strand cDNA synthesis. Sequencing adaptors were then ligated to the double stranded cDNA after purifying with a QIAquick PCR extraction kit. The required fragments (about 200-700 bp) were screened using agarose gel electrophoresis and amplified as sequencing templates via PCR. The final sequencing of the library products was performed using Illumina HiSeq™ 2000 (BGI, Shenzhen, China).

div.head: Sequence filtering, mapping and assessment
div.p: To get clean reads, raw reads were filtered by discarding bad sequences (adaptor reads, N 10% unknown bases, and low quality reads) ( Fig. A.1). A comparison of clean reads was carried out by SOAP aligner/SOAP2 using the reference databases from sea cucumber large scale transcriptome profiling (Sun et al., 2011;Du et al., 2012) allowing no more than 2 base mismatches. Eventually, sequence quality was validated after a series of data assessments consisting of sequence reads quality assessment, sequencing saturation analysis, distribution of reads on reference genes, and gene coverage analysis. The detailed process has been described in our previous work (Sun et al., 2013). The obtained sequences were submitted to NCBI (accession No. GSE51137).

div.head: Gene expression levels and identification of differentially expressed genes (DEGs)
div.p: The number of clean tags exclusively mapped for each gene was counted and normalized by using the RPKM method (reads per kb million reads). Specifically, the computational formula was put forward by Mortazavi et al. (2008) as follows where C is the uniquely aligned number of reads to one gene; N represents the total number of reads which are uniquely aligned to all genes, and L refers to the gene's base number.

By virtue of this standardization, we can detect the transcription levels without deviation by effectively removing the gene length preference and sequencing difference. In cases where there was more than one transcript per gene, the longest transcript was used to calculate its expression level and coverage. To identify DEGs in two libraries, a rigid algorithm developed by Audic and Claverie (1997) was used by setting p values and FDR (false discovery rate). Identification of DEGs was performed as previously described (Sun et al., 2011) by setting FDR ≤0.001 and an absolute value of log 2 Ratio ≥1 in accordance with Audic and Claverie (1997).

div.head: Gene ontology, and pathway enrichment analysis of DEGs
div.p: GO and KEGG analysis can recognize the main functional classifications of DEGs. All DEGs were mapped to gene ontology terms using the GO database (http://www.geneontology.org/) and KEGG (http://www. genome.jp/kegg/), and then the gene numbers of every term were calculated. Finally, a hypergeometric test was used to identify significantly enriched GO terms and pathways in DEGs. GO terms conforming to p-value through Bonferroni Correction ≤0.05 were defined as significantly enriched GO terms. The Q value was used to determine the threshold of p value in multiple tests, and pathways with Q b0.05 were deemed significantly enriched in DEGs.

div.head: qRT-PCR validation
div.p: To validate the RNA-seq results, a set of 25 DEGs was selected to carry out qRT-PCR. Total RNA was isolated as described above for RNA-seq from 8 individuals in each stage (NA, DA and AA) and was used to synthesize first-strand cDNA using a PrimeScript™ RT reagent Kit with gDNA Eraser (Takara, Japan) as the qRT-PCR template. The mRNA expression levels were determined using a SYBR Green® real-time PCR assay (SYBR PrimeScriptTM RT-PCR Kit II, Takara) with an Eppendorf Mastercycler®ep realplex (Eppendorf, Hamburg, Germany). Amplification of genes for 40S ribosomal protein S18, ß-tubulin and NADH dehydrogenase were used as internal controls; expression of these was previously validated as being unchanged during aestivation in the intestine tissue of A. japonicus in an initial study of reference gene stability (unpublished data). The specific primer pairs for the selected DEGs are shown in Table A.1 and were designed based on the sequences obtained from the transcriptome database using the online version of Primer 3.0. PCR efficiencies for each pair of primer were calculated for C t value correction. Each sample was run in triplicate, along with the internal control genes. Melting-curve analysis of the amplification products was performed at the end of the PCR reaction to confirm that only one PCR product was amplified and detected. The 2 − ΔΔCT method was used to analyze the comparative expression levels. And the target genes' C t s were normalized using the geometric mean of these three internal control genes. All data are given as mean ± s.d. (N = 8) and the level of statistical significance was set at p b 0.05. Analysis was carried out using a SPSS16.0 software.

div.head: Sequencing assessment
div.p: To establish a complete transcriptional profile during aestivation, we constructed 3 libraries (NA, DA and AA) for RNA-seq that yielded a total of 3,555,147, 3,613,557 and 3,658,072 clean reads, respectively after filtration. The reference transcriptome from the 454 sequencing of 8 libraries including different developmental stages and adult tissues of A. japonicus provided sufficient EST tags for mapping (Du et al., 2012). As shown in Table 1, 1,826,912(51.39%), 1,749,572(48.42%) and 1,695,661(46.35%) reads were aligned from the above three libraries including 944,773(26.57%), 892,745 (24.71%) and 1,022,383 (27.95%) unique match reads. Previous saturation analysis indicated that 3 million (M) clean reads were already saturated at this platform stage (Fig. A.2) (Sun et al., 2013). Sequencing randomness assessment is based on the distribution of reads residing in the genes. In consideration of the various lengths of reference genes, the reads located on genes were normalized to a relative position (based on gene length and the ratio of reads located on the genes). Our results showed that the reads of various locations on the reference genes were uniformly distributed in the three libraries ( Fig. A.3).

div.head: Identification of DEGs
div.p: We detected a total of 20,712 genes in the intestine of A. japonicus at three stages (NA, DA and AA) by RNA-seq. Based on these genes, DEGs were screened following the criteria of |log 2 Ratio| ≥ 1 and FDR ≤ 0.001. In total, 1245, 1338 and 1321 DEGs were identified from the comparisons of DA vs. NA, AA vs. DA and AA vs. NA, respectively (Fig. 1). For DA vs. NA, we detected 767 up-regulated DEGs (3.7%) and 478 down-regulated DEGs (2.3%) whereas the AA vs. DA comparison produced 607 up-regulated DEGs (2.9%) and 731 down-regulated DEGs (3.5%), and the AA vs. NA comparison yielded 769 up-regulated DEGs (3.7%) and 552 down-regulated DEGs (2.7%). The top 20 upand down-regulated DEGs for DA vs. NA, AA vs. NA, and AA vs. DA are listed in Tables A.2-A.4, respectively. There were occasionally no reads observed for some DEGs in selected libraries, and this resulted in anomalously high fold-changes for these DEGs in the comparison between libraries. In such cases, then, it was difficult to assess the real difference in DEGs. Therefore, we added the next top 10 DEGs with reads N in both libraries in addition to the top 10 DEGs which had 0 reads in one library. Furthermore, some mapped genes with no reference information in the NCBI database could not be annotated. These unknown genes were hard to analyze and so only annotated and recognized DEGs were listed. Three DEGs (proprotein convertase subtilisin/ kexin type 9 preproprotein, Rp2 lipase, and cholinesterase 1) were only expressed in the DA stage, and were more than ten-fold higher than in the NA and AA stages. 1. Changes in the levels of global DEGs in the intestine of sea cucumber at different aestivating stages (DA vs. NA, AA vs. NA, and AA vs. DA). The principle "FDR ≤ 0.001 and the absolute value of log 2 Ratio ≥ 1" was used as a threshold to screen DEGs.

div.head: qRT-PCR validation
div.p: To validate the expression profiles derived from RNA-seq, a set of 25 DEGs from the NA vs. DA group were analyzed by performing qRT-PCR. Among these, 13 genes were up-regulated including proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 preproprotein (PCSK9), trypsinlike serine protease (TLP), betaine-homocysteine S-methyltransferase 1 (MHT1), carboxypeptidase A2 (CPA2), triacylglycerol lipase, pancreatic (PNLIP), preamylase 1 (PML), F-box only protein 32 (FBXO32), glycine Nmethyltransferase (GNMT), follistatin precursor (FS) (Activin-binding protein) (FST), alpha-amylase (AMYA), low-density lipoprotein receptor precursor (LDLR), AMPA receptor GluR2/B, partial (GluR2/B and SI), whereas 12 genes were down-regulated consisting of lactose-binding lectin l-2 (AJL2), lactase-phlorizin hydrolase (LCT LPH), 5,10methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (NADPH) (METF), putative porin precursor (OMPSP), cellular retinol-binding protein type 1b (RBP1B), phosphoserine phosphatase (PSPH), putative porin (OMPS), fatty acid binding protein 2, intestinal (FABP2), antistasin-like protein (ATTP), cytosolic beta-glucosidase (GBA3), ectonucleotide pyrophosphatase/ phosphodiesterase 7 (ENPP7) and dicarbonyl/L-xylulose reductase (DCXR). The results showed that 96% (24 out of 25) of the selected genes exhibited similar trends in relative expression levels via the RT-PCR versus RNA-seq methods, although the fold changes measured by the two methods were often inconsistent (Fig. 2). One gene, MHT1, showed a significant up-regulation during DA (compared with NA) by the RNA-seq method but no change via RT-PCR. Fig. 2. Relative expression levels for 25 DEGs in non-aestivating and deep-aestivating states as determined by qRT-PCR analysis. (A). PCSK9: proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 preproprotein; TLP: trypsin-like serine protease; MHT1: betaine-homocysteine S-methyltransferase 1; CPA2: carboxypeptidase A2; PNLIP: triacylglycerol lipase, pancreatic; PML: preamylase 1; FBXO32: F-box only protein 32; GNMT: glycine N-methyltransferase; FST: follistatin precursor (FS) (Activin-binding protein); AMYA: alpha-amylase; LDLR: low-density lipoprotein receptor precursor; GluR2/B: AMPA receptor GluR2/B, partial; SI: sucrase-isomaltase. (B). AJL2: lactose-binding lectin l-2; LCT LPH: lactase-phlorizin hydrolase; METF: 5,10-methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (NADPH); OMPSP: putative porin precursor; RBP1B: cellular retinol-binding protein type 1b; PSPH: phosphoserine phosphatase; OMPS: putative porin; FABP2: fatty acid binding protein 2, intestinal; ATTP: antistasin-like protein; GBA3: cytosolic beta-glucosidase; ENPP7: ectonucleotide pyrophosphatase/phosphodiesterase 7; DCXR: dicarbonyl/L-xylulose reductase. Values are mean ± s.d. (N = 8). Significantly different from the corresponding NA value, **p b 0.01, *p b 0.05.

div.head: Gene ontology analysis of DEGs
div.p: Gene ontology analysis of the three comparisons (DA vs. NA, AA vs. DA, and AA vs. NA) was performed to ascribe GO categories to 758, 1,012 and 777 DEGs, respectively. Significantly enriched GO categories are presented in Fig. 3. For example, the DEGs associated with "catalytic activity" enriched the most DEGs in the category of "Molecular function" in DA vs. NA. Moreover, we screened the significantly enriched GO terms classified in the biological process category. As indicated in Table 2, for DA vs. NA, 24 metabolic associated processes were highly enriched based on the corrected p value (corrected p value b 0.05). For AA vs. DA, only "pancreas development" was significantly enriched (Table 2, corrected p value b 0.05). For AA vs. NA, 12 substance transport and metabolism associated processes were significantly enriched ( Table 2, corrected p value b 0.05). DEGs classified in these enriched GO terms of the biological process category are presented in supplementary file Table A.5.

div.head: Pathway enrichment analysis of DEGs
div.p: To further explore the biological pathways involved in deep aestivation and arousal from aestivation, enrichment analysis of DEGs was performed. This indicated that most DEGs were enriched in metabolic pathways and signal transduction pathways. In DA vs. NA, a total of 50 pathways were affected by up-regulated DEGs and 50 were affected by down-regulated DEGs, respectively. In AA vs. DA, a total of 26 pathways were affected by up-regulated DEGs and 39 were affected by downregulated DEGs, respectively. In AA vs. NA, a total of 17 pathways were affected by up-regulated DEGs and 73 were affected by down-regulated DEGs, respectively (Table A.6). Significantly enriched pathways were confirmed by Q values b 0.05, which are labeled in bold font. The top 10 enriched pathways for up-or down-regulated DEGs for DA vs. NA, AA vs. DA and AA vs. NA are listed in Tables 4-6, respectively. No pathway was significantly affected by up-regulated DEGs in the DA vs. NA comparison (ie. all had Q values N0.05) but all top 10 pathways were significantly enriched by down-regulated DEGs (Table 3). In the comparison of AA vs. DA, the significantly affected pathways for up-regulated DEGs were ribosome and metabolism of xenobiotics by cytochrome P450, whereas for down-regulated DEGs, all pathways was differentially affected (Table 4). There was only one up-regulated pathway (Ribosome pathway) and six down-regulated pathways that were significantly enriched for AA vs. NA (Table 5). Other non-significantly enriched pathways with up-regulated DEGs were involved in glycometabolism, fat metabolism and amino acid metabolism (Table 5). Note: N is the number of all the genes with GO annotation; n is the number of DEGs in N; M is the number of all the genes that are annotated to the certain GO terms; m is the number of DEGs in M.

div.head: Key DEGs of aestivation and arousal
div.p: Key DEGs associated with aestivation were classified into three groups:

Metabolic enzymes. Key genes involved in carbohydrate catabolism, lipolysis, amino acid metabolism, oxidative phosphorylation, electron transport and TCA cycle (the citric acid cycle) are shown in Table 6. Most genes associated with carbohydrate catabolism were downregulated during aestivation except for preamylase 1, alpha-amylase and sucrase-isomaltase during deep-aestivation which was elevated. All these expression changes were reversed during the arousal stage. In addition, various lipases showed sharply increased mRNA levels in deep aestivation that decreased in the arousal stage, whereas several other genes that encode for proteins of fatty acid metabolism were expressed at lower levels during deep-aestivation compared to non-aestivation and arousal stages. Except for cysteine dioxygenase, genes participating in various kinds of amino acid metabolism were observed to be down-regulated during the deep-aestivation stage and were up-regulated in arousal. Lower expression levels were observed in all oxidative phosphorylation, electron transport and TCA related genes during aestivation than in non-aestivation and arousal stages.

Detoxification and tissue protection relevant genes. Genes encoding enzymes/proteins with functions in detoxification and tissue protection are summarized in three functional categories (Table 7): antioxidant protection, metabolism of xenobiotics, and immune defense. Most DEGs belong to the former two groups and almost all enzymes in these categories showed reduced gene expression during aestivation. The exceptions were copper/zinc superoxide dismutase and cytochrome P450 Arginine and proline metabolism 0.02134489 1.654229E−01 that showed strong increases in expression levels during the deep-aestivation stage. Ten out of sixteen enzymes in these two categories showed increased gene expression during arousal from aestivation, in some cases rebounding to NA levels but others showed sustained low expression. Immune defense relevant genes were strongly up-regulated during aestivation as compared to non-aestivation and arousal stages. Energy-expensive processes. Table 8 shows the responses of genes that encode proteins and enzymes involved in energy-expensive processes such as ion motive ATPases, fuel biosynthesis, protein translation and protein degradation. Expressions of these were all strongly suppressed at the mRNA level during deep aestivation (except for elongation factor 1-beta). However, after arousal from aestivation, the majority of these were up-regulated again.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In our study, a large scale transcript analysis of mRNA expression levels was performed for the first time using libraries from the intestines of adult A. japonicus sampled at three key stages of the aestivation cycle (non-aestivation, deep-aestivation, and arousal from aestivation) acquired by Illumina/Solexa Technology. The results indicated that 3 M clean reads had reached saturation and could meet the needs of further analysis on this platform, as previously reported (Sun et al., 2013). Strict data quality control and conservative matching may result in the loss of substantial sequence information, but reveals the most robust and bona fide differences (Wu et al., 2010).

To further confirm gene expression profiles, qRT-PCR analysis of 25 selected DEGs was conducted. It was observed that expression trends of genes analyzed by qRT-PCR were similar to those detected by Solexa sequencing, although the expression fold changes of many genes had obvious discrepancies. This may probably be attributed to differences in the sensitivity for estimation of gene expression. Solexa sequencing has been reported to be more sensitive for determining gene expression levels, particularly for low-abundance transcripts (Tang et al., 2009;Wang et al., 2009b). Differences might also be attributed to the fact that pooled samples were used in Solexa sequencing, whereas tissue samples from individual animals were tested in the qRT-PCR studies.

Gene expression profiling and characterization has greatly contributed to the study and exploration of dormancy phenomena in many species and is gradually allowing the acquisition of a global overview of gene expression patterns and identification of key functional proteins that provide the common regulatory mechanisms of hypometabolism (Morin and Storey, 2009;Storey and Storey, 2010;Loong et al., 2012;Reilly et al., 2013;Schwartz et al., 2013). Du et al. (2012) previously identified 446 DEGs (aestivation vs. active) from an analysis of combined tissues (intestine, respiratory tree, coelomic fluid) of A. japonicus using 454 life sequencing. Their work provided unprecedented abundance transcriptome information for this species but has been improved in our study in three main ways: a) the sequencing depth of Solexa (our present study) is much greater than for 454 life sequencing, and allowed us to identify 1245 DEGs (DA vs. NA), 1338 DEGs (AA vs. DA) and 1321 DEGs (AA vs. NA) in the present study; b) previous work only focused on non-aestivation and aestivation stages, but ours added crucial information about the early arousal from aestivation and the gene responses needed to return to the active state and to re-proliferate intestinal tissue; and c) our focus on the intestine alone allowed tissue-specific genes to be identified since it is known that stress, disease or physiological states can elicit different gene expression responses by different tissues (Slaugenhaupt et al., 2001;Li et al., 2005). What's more, we only found 4 DEGs overlap between 446 DEGs (aestivation vs. active) from Du et al.'s and our DA vs. NA comparison. Hence, our study is a crucial advancement to the overall understanding of the role of gene expression in aestivation.

In our study, a number of DEGs were shown to be differentially expressed during key stages of aestivation in A. japonicus. For example, as shown in Table A.2, lactase-phlorizin hydrolase was significantly under-expressed during deep aestivation compared with non-aestivation, whereas cubilin-like (involved in protein transport) and trypsin-like serine protease (involved in protein hydrolysis), were significantly over-expressed in DA vs. NA. These results are consistent with a shift in metabolic fuel use from carbohydrates to protein occurring when animals entered into deep aestivation (Yang et al., 2005(Yang et al., , 2006. Transportation and fuel synthesis related DEGs (putative Note: RPKM is the abbreviation of normalized gene expression levels; ↑ represents up-regulated levels of expression. ↓ represents down-regulated levels of expression. "-"represents no expression was detected.

porin-like, phosphoserine phosphatase and ribophorin II-like) were also under-expressed in DA vs. NA probably to contribute to energy-saving for long term survival. Several acute phase proteins involving serum amyloid protein A and C-type lectin domain protein precursor were significantly over-expressed in DA vs. NA suggesting that self-defense mechanisms respond to hypometabolism. This is consistent with the results from hibernating animals that found that acute phase proteins (serum alpha2 macroglobulin and haptoglobin) were over-expressed during hibernation (Sheikh et al., 2003;Tsiouris et al., 2004). When it comes to AA vs. NA, the data indicates that the intestines begin to recover from aestivation quite quickly. This process is similar to the intestine regeneration process in sea cucumbers since they both endured proliferation and development (Sun et al., 2013). During this process, genes such as tenascin-R, neurogenic locus notch homolog protein 2, and beta-tubulin were up-regulated to promote neurogenesis and neuron regeneration for activating various biological functions during recovery (Fournier and McKerracher, 1997;Roskams et al., 1998;Jones and Jones, 2000;Hansson et al., 2004). Matriptase, a transmembrane serine protease involved in formation and development of intestinal epidermis (List et al., 2002;Buzza et al., 2010) was also overexpressed during arousal from aestivation, suggesting that the degenerated intestine during aestivation is returning to a state where it is ready to deal with ingested food. The expression level of lactasephlorizin hydrolase also rebounded and this could also indicate that maybe the intestine is renewing its ability to deal with food and glycometabolism is beginning to be re-established in order to provide enough energy for recovery. In addition, many genes in the top DEGs list, such as low-density lipoprotein-related protein and proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 that are related to intestinal digestion, absorption, and metabolism, also showed obvious changes of expression level during the AA stage.

div.head: Functional classification of DEGs
div.p: For a better understanding of the functional classification of DEGs during aestivation, GO enrichment analysis was conducted to compare DA vs. NA, AA vs. DA, and AA vs. NA. As expected, the significantly enriched GO terms that were identified in the present study are mainly associated with metabolic process and substance transport, which is similar to the findings for hibernating animals (Williams et al., 2005). For DA vs. NA, the frequency of genes in the GO category "metabolic process" was enriched in the lists of down-regulated genes in the intestine of torpid animals, relative to active animals. The data provides supporting evidence that aestivation in A. japonicus involves coordination of multiple metabolic processes to maintain homeostasis with extremely limited energy.

Arousal from aestivation is characterized by recovery of the intestine tissue mass and restoration of function and normal metabolism. The intestines from sea cucumbers at the arousal stage exhibited a gradual increasing length and thickening of layers along with a new proliferation of microvilli in the mucous epithelium, which is similar to the regeneration process of the intestine (Su et al., 2012). For AA vs. DA, DEGs mapped only to the enriched GO term "pancreas development" and proved to be ribosomal proteins those were up-regulated to support renewed protein synthesis, as part of the intestine recovery. Other DEGs that were upregulated in AA were involved in transmembrane transport, such as "organic substance transport", "lipid transport", "organic acid transport" and "carboxylic acid transport". These may be associated with renewed accumulation of the nutrients needed to provide energy and building blocks for biosynthesis as the intestine recovers.

div.head: Pathway analysis
div.p: The enriched pathway analysis played a key role in identifying the most strongly affected pathways involved in the metabolic responses of A. japonicus during aestivation. For example, the renin-angiotensin system is widely known for its important role in maintaining body fluid homeostasis (Corvol et al., 1995) and in invertebrates it involved in osmoregulation, memory processes, reproduction and immune response modulation (Delorenzi and Maldonado, 1999;Salzet et al., 2001). Genes involved in this pathway were significantly downregulated during deep-aestivation compared to active status, which suggests that these energy-consuming processes are silenced during deep-aestivation. Glycometabolism related pathways including galactose metabolism, glycolysis/gluconeogenesis and pyruvate metabolism were also affected during hypometabolism. Enrichment of significantly Note: RPKM is the abbreviation of normalized gene expression levels; ↑ represents up-regulated levels of expression; ↓ represents down-regulated levels of expression. "-"represents no expression was detected.

down-regulated genes in these pathways supported the idea that controlling glycolytic rate is a universal way to suppress metabolic rate in both vertebrates and invertebrates during hypometabolism (Brooks and Storey, 1997;Frick et al., 2008a;Groom et al., 2013). Although there were no significantly enriched pathways among up-regulated DEGs in DA vs. NA, the "fat digestion and absorption" pathway did attract our attention. Many genes such as Rp2 lipase and triacylglycerol lipase were identified as up-regulated during deep-aestivation, which suggests that A. japonicus may switch to endogenous lipid stores as their principal fuel source during the summer aestivating season. Groom et al. (2013) and Shao et al. (2010) also proposed that animals prefer to use lipid fuels to carbohydrates during hibernation and aestivation (Shao et al., 2010;Groom et al., 2013). It is no surprise that the "Ribosome" pathway was significantly enriched by up-regulated DEGs during AA compared to DA and NA, because protein synthesis is needed for rebuilding an intact and functional digestive system. Another significantly enriched pathway for AA vs. DA is metabolism of xenobiotics by cytochrome P450, which suggests the importance of body defense during recovery. All activities of the arousal animals including feeding, digesting, normal movement and restoring defense and immune mechanism all require fuel support. Therefore, fuel metabolism related pathways, especially carbohydrate metabolism, were observed to exhibit elevated expression levels during arousal.

div.head: Key DGEs associated with aestivation and arousal from aestivation
div.p: Metabolic genes: Metabolic rate depression is a common strategy for many organisms experiencing environmental stress conditions and underlies phenomena including aestivation, hibernation, diapause, and others. Most of the key genes involved in glycolysis, amino acid metabolism and mitochondrial function showed down-regulated trends during deep-aestivation and expression was re-activated during arousal from aestivation (Table 7). Genes involved in lipolysis showed the opposite expression pattern. These metabolic genes are excellent candidates for further study of the regulation of fuel sources during aestivation. Cytochrome c oxidase subunit Va and NADH dehydrogenase iron-sulfur protein 8, mitochondrial-like isoform 2, which are essential enzymes of the respiratory chain, both showed decreased mRNA levels in our screen during DA, which is consistent with the results reported in aestivating lungfish Protopterus dolloi and Protopterus annectens (Frick et al., 2010;Loong et al., 2012). Down-regulation of ATP synthase and malate dehydrogenase (MDH) was also consistent with mitochondrial quiescence, which was also reported in green-striped burrowing frog, Cyclorana alboguttata, which showed a 67% decrease in ATP synthase activity during aestivation (Hudson et al., 2006). These results also supported our previous work that showed that A. japonicus suppressed metabolic rate in aestivation as evidenced by a reduced oxygen consumption rate and respire-somatic index (Yang et al., 2006;Ji et al., 2008). Glycogen is an efficient storage form of glucose and can be used as a metabolic fuel by organisms during torpor. However, glycogen reserves are often low in comparison with the fuel supplies available as lipids and, furthermore, glycogen is often reserved to fuel those tissues that cannot use lipid fuels (e.g. in mammals these typically include the brain and erythrocytes). Similarly, a very low content of glycogen was reported in sea cucumber tissues although a significant increase in tissue glycogen content was found during aestivation (Gao, 2008). This suggests that glycogen stores may still contribute to energy supply during aestivation although protein and lipid fuels are dominant in sea cucumber tissues. Hexokinase (HK) as a key flux-generating enzyme in the glycolytic pathway (Stryer, 1981), and in the present study, HK gene expression was down-regulated in the deep-aestivation stage which may suggest that the catabolism of glucose received from extracellular sources is suppressed. Flux-generating enzymes of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA), pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) and citrate synthase (CS), were also down-regulated in the intestine of aestivating sea cucumbers. The increased glycogen levels and decreased expression of HK and PDH both support the idea that carbohydrate catabolism is suppressed in aestivation. Reduced PDH activity is common in other hypometabolic systems including snail estivation and mammalian hibernation (Brooks and Storey, 1992;Storey and Storey, 2007). Down-regulation of CS indicates an overall suppression of TCA cycle activity and this is similar to the results from aestivating African lungfish (Protopterus dolloi) and land snail (Otala lactea) (Brooks and Storey, 1990;Frick et al., 2008a).

In our study, lipid metabolism in A. japonicus aestivation was also intriguing. The up-regulation of lipase and acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase (ACAD) suggested increased lipolysis and β-oxidation, respectively, during aestivation. We infer that increased lipid oxidation is derived from endogenous reserves, which is supported by Jangoux and Lawrence (1982), who demonstrated that the intestines of other echinoderms, Trachythyone elongata and Holothuria scabra, were rich in lipids and proteins and these served as energy reserves during aestivation or reproduction periods. FBP 2 (fatty acid binding protein 2, intestinal) that is responsible for assimilation of dietary lipids in the intestine by intracellular transportation of long-chain fatty acids (Albala et al., 2006;Storch and Thumser, 2010) exhibited reduced expression, which is consistent with a general reduction in nutrient uptake/processing capacity of the intestine during aestivation. Genes involved in amino acid metabolism were also down-regulated during sea cucumber deep aestivation such as aspartate aminotransferase and phosphoserine aminotransferase. Contrary to our observations, Frick et al. (2008b) found increased activities of aspartate aminotransferase in African lungfish P. dolloi during aestivation (Frick et al., 2008b). However, lungfish need to accumulate free amino acids and urea as defenses against osmotic stress in a desiccating environment during aestivation (Schmuck and Linsenmair, 1997;Cartledge et al., 2008).

Detoxification and tissue protection relevant genes: Defense and protection strategies that respond to aestivation differ in various aestivating species, depending on the environmental stresses involved and the physiological characteristics of tissues/animals. For example, most of the intracellular antioxidant enzymes showed increased expression in brain tissue of aestivating lungfish P. dolloi, whereas significant decreases were detected in the activities of catalase in kidney and hepatopancreas, and glutathione peroxidase in kidney of Helix pomatia snails during aestivation (Nowakowska et al., 2009;Page et al., 2010). Such contradictions may arise for two reasons: first, different aestivating species may have a preference for different adaptive defense mechanisms, since antioxidant enzymes are only one kind of cellular response to stresses (Kültz, 2003); second, one antioxidant enzyme may play different roles in various tissues and species (Ramos-Vasconcelos and Hermes-Lima, 2003;Nowakowska et al., 2009). A series of flexible defense strategies seem to have been adopted in aestivating A. japonicus. As shown in Table 8, the intestine of aestivating A. japonicus retained self-immune defense functions while suppressing a majority of the antioxidant protection genes except for copper/zinc superoxide dismutase (Cu/Zn SOD) and cytochrome P450. Other researchers also described the up-regulation of SOD expression in different tissues during sea cucumber aestivation (Wang et al., 2011;Du et al., 2012;Klanian, 2013). So we can infer that Cu/Zn SOD plays a main role in antioxidant defense and tissue protection during A. japonicus aestivation. It also has been reported that the upregulation of expression of cytochrome P450 genes at moderately elevated temperatures in coral Acropora millepora suggesting that upregulation of cytochrome P450 during aestivation is probably a positive adaptive defense mechanism by A. japonicus in response to heat stress (Rosic et al., 2010).

The innate immune system is also an important defense mechanism in A. japonicus consisting of humoral and cellular responses when confronted with microorganisms or acute stress (Smith and Davidson, 1994;Wang et al., 2008bWang et al., , 2009a. Previous work found that A. japonicus exhibited significant changes in the immune characteristics of coelomic fluid during aestivation (Wang et al., 2008a). Changes in immune characteristics have also been reported for other aestivators such as the up-regulation of the mannan-binding lectin-associated serine protease (MASP) of the lectin pathway of the innate immune response in aestivating African lungfish P. annectens (Loong et al., 2012). In our work, lysozyme, C-type lectin and complement factor B-2 all showed significant increases in gene expression levels during aestivation, adding to the previous observations of Wang et al. (2008a) and further indicating that immune defense plays important roles in aestivation.

Energy-expensive processes: Suppression of the rates of energyexpensive metabolic processes is a crucial part of long term survival in aestivation and other forms of hypometabolism. By reducing the rate of ATP consumption, organisms gain an extension of the time that their fixed endogenous fuel reserves can sustain survival. Ion motive ATPases are major energy consumers in cells; for example, in some cell types, the Na + /K + ATPase ion pump can consume as much as 40% of total ATP turnover (Clausen, 1986). Not surprisingly, both aestivating snails (O. lactea) and hibernating ground squirrels (Spermophilus lateralis) greatly reduced Na + /K + ATPase activities during hypometabolism (MacDonald and Storey, 1999;Ramnanan and Storey, 2006). In the current study, we also detected down-regulated expression of Na + / K + ATPase during deep-aestivation.

Another energy-consuming process is protein turnover including protein synthesis and degradation. Previous studies have demonstrated that global protein synthesis is inhibited in both vertebrates and invertebrates during aestivation (Fuery et al., 1998;Pakay et al., 2002;Ramnanan et al., 2009;Storey and Storey, 2010). Eukaryotic translation initiation factor 2(eIF2) that brings Met-tRNA i into the ribosome, and eukaryotic translation initiation factor 4(eIF4) that mediates the recruitment of ribosomes to mRNA are critical regulatory factors in the translation process (Voorma et al., 1994;Kimball, 1999). EIF2, eIF4 and several ribosomal proteins all showed decreased expression levels in our study indicating that suppression of protein synthesis occurred in A. japonicus intestine during aestivation. Similar evidence of down-regulation of protein synthesis has also been reported for both frog and snail aestivators (Pakay et al., 2003;Ramnanan et al., 2009). In A. japonicus, down-regulation of the ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme E2I and the proteasome was also detected, indicating that suppression of proteolysis pathways are also important parts of hypometabolism. Similarly, activity of the 20S proteasome was suppressed by 60-80% in hepatopancreas of aestivating O. lactea (Ramnanan et al., 2009). Suppression of proteolysis during hypometabolism was also indicated by reduced levels of ubiquitinconjugated proteins in response to anoxia in embryos of the brine shrimp Artemia franciscana (Anchordoguy and Hand, 1994).

In conclusion, our RNA-seq strategy for analyzing the differential expression of A. japonicus intestine genes between active, deepaestivating and arousal states provided an informative approach to study the molecular basis of aestivation in marine invertebrates. Analysis gained by this study will be useful for future aestivation studies on sea cucumbers and offer a series of key candidate genes and pathways that underlie regulation of metabolism, detoxification and energy-expensive processes in marine aestivators.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at http://dx. doi.org/10.1016/j.cbd.2014.02.002.
